POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of this project is to investigate various invariants of three- and four-dimensional spaces from gauge theory and symplectic geometry. Both gauge theory and symplectic geometry have their origins in physics, where they are used as mathematical frameworks to describe the dynamics of our universe. The effort to determine the shape of our universe, which we perceive as a four-dimensional space—three spatial dimensions plus the time dimension—has led to a successful collaboration between mathematics and physics, and the development of a prolific line of research in mathematics where one investigates fine properties of spaces that remain unchanged under deformations. Such properties are called invariants.

The main outcomes of this research are the content of two articles, joint with Yi-Jen Lee and Clifford H. Taubes, which complete the series of articles proving the equivalence of two invariants, the monopole Floer homology and Heegaard Floer homology, one defined via gauge theory and the other via symplectic geometry. This resolves a ten-year-old conjecture posed by the mathematicians who introduced these invariants. Although equivalent, these two invariants have very different definitions, and different strengths. Knowing that they are equivalent allows one to port these strengths from one side to the other so as to answer other open questions or conjectures. There have already been instances where others have used this equivalence to prove new results. Another outcome of the project is an article in preparation by the PI, which introduces a new invariant of knots in the context of gauge theory.  Among other things, the development of such an invariant could be used to extend the equivalence of monopole Floer homology and Heegaard Floer homology  to the equivalence of their associated numerical invariants for four-dimensional spaces. Such an equivalence would be useful in a similar manner to the equivalence of the invariants of three-dimensional spaces.
